Reference: Brown Planthopper: Threat to Rice Production in Asia, International Rice Research Institute 1979. Available online: http://books.irri.org/9711040220_content.pdf

Other Favourable Conditions: Populations increase at end of rainy season and are more common in rainfed rice.
Fluctuating temperatures with a mean of 24C are most favourable for development. Flowering maize is most attractive to the moth.
High humidity and young plants, <15 days old required for infection. Older plants appear not to be infected
Notes: Based on isolates from Zimbabwe, there may be slight differences in isolates as suggested in the referenced paper. However, I cannot find any studies for SE Asia to reference.

Other Favourable Conditions: Favoured by soil moisture >80% water holding capacity
Whiteflies. Poor sanitation, planting infected or poor-quality cuttings, poor in-season management (lack of roguing within crop stands)
Transmitted mechanically and by infected seed
Constant rainfall and splashes disperse inoculum

Crop: *These temperatures are either lethal or the boundary at which the organism can survive and reproduce.
